Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Next Generation Imaging of Magmatic Processes beneath the Juan de Fuca Ridge using MCS data
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed work aims to expand upon previous studies at Axial volcano, particularly a 2002 research cruise there, and seeks to: 1) process the remaining Axial multichannel seismic (MCS) profiles from that cruise; 2) process two "repeat" profiles from the 2002 cruise to identify any differences in overall structure after the 2011 eruption and better image the internal and basal magma chamber reflections using an additional 2 km of offset in the new data; 3) reprocess select along- and cross-axis profiles from the Endeavor and Cleft segments of the Juan de Fuca ridge to examine differences in crustal accretion using new methods; and 4) extend these methods to aging crust in poorly and heavily sedimented environments.

Broader Impacts: The proposed work will provide more detailed images of sub-seafloor structure along the Juan de Fuca Ridge, particularly across Axial volcano. The results will lead to better understanding of the crustal processes at the mid-ocean ridge locations.The results of the project will be used to create a "ridge to subduction" virtual tour of plate tectonics through Cascadia for the National Seismological Laboratory at the University of Nevada, Reno which is visited annually by many K-8 students. A postdoctoral researcher will be supported.

Institution.Name: University of California-San Diego Scripps Inst of Oceanography

POR.DRECONTENT:
A primary goal of volcanology is to relate surface observations such as eruptions, lava flows, and venting to processes within the underlying magma chamber and to the pathways that deliver magma to the surface. It is much easier to geologically map and monitor subaerial volcanoes than submarine ones due to their better accessibility, and land seismic experiments designed to probe the internal structure, might appear to have a similar advantage. However, difficult logistics means most such experiments are restricted to a relatively sparse set of sources and receivers spaced kilometers apart and refraction geometries, which limits resolution. In a marine setting, we can efficiently use a ship for multichannel seismic (MCS) surveying and achieve source and receiver spacings of 10-40 m and, in principle, a much better resolved image of the internal structure a submarine volcano. Improved imaging of submarine volcanoes, taking advantage of this denser coverage, has been a primary objective of the research.

 

Axial volcano lies 480 km off of the coast of Oregon on the axis of the Juan de Fuca ridge, a seafloor spreading center. The magma supply for Axial volcano comes not only from seafloor spreading but also from the Cobb hotspot, which for the last ~0.5 Ma has been collocated with the ridge. Consequently, Axial is the most active submarine volcano in the Northeast Pacific with eruptions in 1998, 2011, and 2015. Axial has become a focus site for the adaptation of subaerial methods to the mapping and monitoring of a submarine volcano and is now monitored in real time through a cabled instrument array connected to shore. The summit of Axial volcano is dominated a large 3x8 km caldera that connects the north and the south rift zones, the primary features fed by the volcano.

 

Our research has focussed on a grid of twelve MCS profiles covering the summit caldera and the southeast flank and on the improved imaging of the geometry and internal structure of the underlying magma chamber. The improved imaging was a multistep process that included downward continuation, travel time tomography and waveform inversion to image the velocity structure, and finally reverse time migration to image the magma chamber and internal fracture network. Downward continuation significantly aids the construction of velocity models by transforming the MCS dataset recorded at the sea-surface into one resembling a seafloor experiment, removing much of the initial complexity in the seismic wavefield. The resolution of tomography, which uses travel times, is helped by the dense spatial sampling, but waveform inversion, which also uses the amplitude and shape of seismic arrivals, go further, resulting in the resolution of features of ~100 m. With a good velocity model, we can better focus seismic reflections during migration yielding a sharper image of the magma reservoir and other internal structures. 

 

The seismic imaging reveals a main magma reservoir 1-2 km beneath the summit of Axial volcano that is 14 km long, 3 km wide and up to 1 km thick, aligned almost with the caldera but displaced slightly to the east and extending beyond both ends, Figure 1. This magma reservoir is an order of magnitude larger than is typically seen beneath a similar length of spreading center. A less well defined secondary magma reservoir present on the southeast flank of the volcano. The collapse of the caldera can be traced at depth in the velocity images by offsets of the velocity horizons (Figure 1a) or as a drop-down in the high-velocity gradient region (Figure 1b). The larger offset at depth than at the surface indicates that the caldera formed 30-60 kya is, by geologic standards, filling rapidly with lava flows. Material above the high-velocity gradient is highly porous and is inferred to be primarily fractured and fissured lava flows. The higher velocities within the caldera indicate generally lower porosity, perhaps due to the confinement of lava flows to the caldera or to rapid hydrothermal alteration. 

 

The internal structure of the main magma chamber is not simple but contains multiple high and low amplitude reflectors, Figure 1c, suggesting stacked magma sills and zonation of the magma chamber into regions of high and low melt fraction. If this is the case, then we could expect magmas with different chemical characteristics to coexist within the reservoir and that only small portions of the reservoir would be eruptable. Indeed although the estimated volume of the main reservoir is 18-30 km3, the volume of individual events - dikes injected along the rift zones and erupted flows are only 0.1-0.2 km3.

The migrated images also reveal networks of fractures mostly connected to the magma reservoir. These are related not only to the caldera collapse but are also inferred to be deformation related fractures produced by magma intrusion and periodic inflation of the reservoir.


 


Last Modified: 08/11/2016
Modified by: Alistair J Harding

Image
  • Cutaway views of Axial volcano, looking toward the north rift zone showing the main magma reservoir beneath the horseshoe shaped caldera and the inferred fracture pattern (black lines). Structure is shown as (a) velocity, (b) velocity gradient, and (c) reflectivity.
    Alistair Harding & Adrien Arnulf
    Copyrighted
    Alistair J Harding
    Cutaway view of Axial Volcano
